awd_titl_txt: Wave Glider Observations of Surface Fluxes and Mixed-layer Processes in the Southern Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Surface and upper-ocean processes in the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) play an important role in ocean heat transport, air-sea gas fluxes (such as pCO2) and in sea-ice formation. The net of these in turn modulate global climate, sea level rise and global circulation.  This project  continues the field development of a surface autonomous vehicle (https://www.liquid-robotics.com/wave-glider/overview/ ) to better measure and study these processes in the remote Southern Ocean, where continuous data is otherwise very difficult to obtain. Mobile autonomous surface vehicles, powered by sunlight and wave action provide a very cost effective manner of solving the problem of obtaining  unattended observational coverage in the remote Southern Ocean. The project will support ongoing education and outreach efforts by the PIs including school presentations, visits to science centers and the development of educational materials.

The WaveGlider has an established track record of navigating successful spatial surveys and positioned time series measurements in otherwise inhospitable waters and sea-states. The study includes the addition of some new measurement capabilities such as an (upper mixed) layer profiling CTD winch, a high frequency acoustic Doppler turbulence system, and a biogeochemical chlorophyll fluorescence sensor. This augmented instrumentation package will be used for a set of Austral summer season experiments observing ocean-shelf exchange along with frontal air-sea interactions in the vicinity of the West Antarctic Peninsula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

Air-sea interaction in the Southern Ocean connects the "conveyor belt" overturning circulations in each the major oceans of the world (Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian), providing the long-term memory of the climate system by determining the rates of oceanic heat and carbon storage over tens to hundreds of years as well as the supply of heat to melt Antarctic ice shelves. With the goal of enhancing our ability to study these air-sea interaction processes through sustained autonomous presence in remote locations, our project conducted two deployments of a wave-propelled robotic surface vehicle (Wave Glider) near Palmer Station for extended missions around Drake Passage and the Antarctic Peninsula. Over 3 months in 2016-17 and 4 months in 2019-20, the Wave Glider conducted time series stations and surveys of the Polar Front (one of the intense jets of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current). The vehicle also collected multiple instances of calibration data by positioning itself near the tracks of passing Antarctic research vessels.

Although these first extended deployments revealed some important limitations in the Wave Glider's durability and its ability to maintain solar battery charging in the high-latitude Antarctic, the results have laid the groundwork for future Wave Glider missions. The second field season included a new profiling winch system for subsurface temperature and salinity sampling, and although it only survived for a few profiles it demonstrated its potential in addition to clarifying likely failure modes. Subsequent deployments with a smaller self-recording CTD package have been more successful.

Intellectual Merit

The scientific goals of the Southern Ocean Wave Glider mission included the measurement of rapid wind variations (both the hourly changes of fast-moving storms and the second-to-second fluctuations of boundary layer turbulence) and small-scale horizontal structure in the ocean's near-surface currents, temperature, and salinity. These, along with the surface wave field, have important impacts on the rates of air-sea transfer of momentum and heat (which, in turn, drives the ocean circulation). Through the measurements collected, we have been able to demonstrate that a Wave Glider is able to collect reliable measurements of surface conditions (including turbulence) and will be a valuable tool for improving momentum and heat transfer estimates.

Over the course of its missions, the Wave Glider's multiple crossings of the Polar Front illustrated the response of both air temperature and winds to ocean surface temperature, as well as the impact that surface currents have on the surface wave field.

Findings from comparing wind, wave, and turbulence measurements indicate that a new wave-based theory provides improved measurements of wind forcing in most cases, while an older simpler theory continues to work better in others. The reasons for these different situations are still being investigated, but they are at least partially related to the fact that waves in the Southern Ocean are not purely driven by the local winds but can travel long distances over many days and also undergo modification by the strong currents along the way.

Broader Impacts

The work done in this project has advanced our capability for Southern Ocean science and clarified the advantages and disadvantages of using autonomous surface vehicles to make extended observations. Even in the strong Antarctic Circumpolar Current, the Wave Glider is able to conduct surveys and hold station, provided that satellite maps of the currents are used to guide the vehicle piloting. Future missions of 4-6 months duration in the Southern Hemisphere summer are entirely viable and will continue to conduct scientific studies that cannot be accomodated by the overtaxed Antarctic research vessel fleet.

The emerging relationship between surface currents and the wave field points to ways that coupled climate forecasts can be improved by taking these impacts on the drag law into account. Wind drag on the ocean determines how a strengthening of Southern Ocean winds due to increased greenhouse gases will translate into a response in the Circumpolar Current, with cascading consequences for the oceanic overturning circulation and Antarctic ecosystems.

Finally, the novel concept of the robotic Wave Glider and its role in Antarctic research has immense capacity to inspire and serve as a venue for public-facing outreach and education. All members of the research team continue to give general audience presentations, both locally (through science centers in Seattle) and nationally (through blogs, press releases, and live broadcasts from sea).
